physDesc.p: This letter is three pages long. It is not typed on Amy Lowell’s stationery. The word “Poetry” is penciled in at the top of the first page.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following: The Pound feud

div.p: The Literary Editor of "The Boston American" has occasionally permitted me to write reviews. They are anonymous which is the one drawback from my point of view as when one wishes to praise a friend one wishes to have all the world know how highly one thinks of her. But Mr. Williams has only one signed article in his paper and that is his own. Now it occurs to me that he may permit me to write a review of your book for him. Ever since I got your letter yesterday morning I have been trying to get hold of him by telephone and he has always been out. But I think I shall be able to round him up before very long and I trust that he will not turn down my suggestion.

The paper has a large circulation and I think it ought to be a good place. At any rate it is the only paper except Margaret Anderson's "Little Review" which I write for and I think it will be better for me not to do it in a Chicago paper owing
to being in the family, as it were, and so this seems distinctly the best arrangement.
I am very much afraid that Ezra may try his best to injure me owing to his fury at that unfortunate advertisement. It would therefore be a great kindness to me if you could review my book somewhat at length as all his friends in England see "Poetry" and a few nice words will do a great deal toward allaying the impression which he is trying to give. Not only do his letters to me show his state of mind but Richard Aldington writes me that he is being very nasty.
Funnily enough I do not feel angry with him, merely very sad and rather disillusioned. I thought him a different man. But I do not want to obviate as much as possible the effects of his venomous pen and his still more venomous tongue on my poor little book. I am unpopular enough and misunderstood enough by the poets of other schools without having this one turn and rend me.
In contradistinction the fine loyalty and generosity of the Aldingtons stands out like a shining torch.
It is ridiculous for I certainly never in[sentence cut off] his feelings and I wish I had
never suggested the anthology as I certainly never would have done so had I supposed he would not come into it. However that cannot be helped now, only I beg you to give me a helping hand through this exceedingly hard moment.
The November number has not come, I am most anxious to see it. Affectionately yours,
